content: More than 53,000 commercial vessels travel the world's waters, regulated by international protocols and U.S. laws to prevent pollution. The cruise industry, a small fraction of the shipping industry, has drawn attention for its environmental impacts. The cruise industry, representing a small fraction of the global shipping industry, has grown significantly, contributing $40 billion to the U.S. economy in 2009. With over 230 ships worldwide, the majority are foreign-flagged, and six companies own nearly 95% of passenger ships in U.S. waters. The industry has seen a 7.4% annual growth in cruise passengers since 1990, hosting 14.3 million passengers in 2010. New ships are continuously added to the fleet, becoming larger, more luxurious, and accommodating more passengers and crew. The cruise industry, dominated by six companies with foreign-flag vessels, continues to grow with larger and more luxurious ships accommodating increasing numbers of passengers and crew. The industry faces challenges in managing waste disposal and ensuring safety for passengers and visited communities. A large cruise ship can generate significant amounts of sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, and other waste during a typical one-week voyage. The volume of wastes produced by large cruise ships is greater than that of many small cities on land. During a one-week voyage, a ship can generate 210,000 gallons of sewage, 1 million gallons of graywater, 130 gallons of hazardous wastes, 8 tons of solid waste, and 25,000 gallons of oily bilge water. Improper disposal of these wastes poses risks to human health and the environment. Concerns have been raised about the adequacy of laws for managing cruise ship waste, with weak enforcement noted. Foreign-flag cruise ships have been involved in numerous illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters, with 83% of cases involving discharges of various waste streams. Between 1993 and 1998, foreign-flag cruise ships were involved in 87 confirmed illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters, with 83% of cases involving oil or oil-based products. Most discharges were accidental, some intentional, and a few undetermined.
